source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk2
evidence_span: In the case of tension stresses, the irradiation creep diameter strains are positive, which is reasonable. In the case of compression stresses greater than $- 1 6 ~ \mathrm { M P a }$ , the irradiation creep diameter strains are negative, which is reasonable. However, in the total hoop stress region from 0 to $- 1 6 \mathrm { M P a }$ (see the dashed line in Fig. 7), compression stresses result in positive irradiation creep diameter strains. Although this result is technically correct, the result is physically unreasonable.

evidence_span: In Zircaloys, the primary microstructural feature that affects corrosion is the presence of second phase particles (SPPs).

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: The SPPs formed in Zircaloy-2 are $\mathrm { Z r } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { C r } ) _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { Z r } _ { 2 } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { N i } )$ , and the matrix is depleted in Fe, Cr, and Ni.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: In addition to irradiation damage, the main microstructural change in Zircaloys is radiation-induced dissolution of the SPPs.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: The result is a decrease in the number density of the SPPs and at sufficiently large fluences or irradiation times; the SPPs can become completely dissolved.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: For the $\mathrm { Z r } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { C r } ) _ { 2 }$ SPPs, the dissolution rate of Fe is faster than that of $\mathrm { C r }$ ,resulting in the SPP becoming enriched in $\mathrm { C r }$ as the SPP dissolves.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: For the $\mathrm { Z r } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { C r } ) _ { 2 }$ SPPs, the dissolution rate of Fe is faster than that of $\mathrm { C r }$ ,resulting in the SPP becoming enriched in $\mathrm { C r }$ as the SPP dissolves.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: $\mathrm { Z r } _ { 2 } ( \mathrm { F e } , \mathrm { N i } )$ EPY SPPs appear to dissolve without appreciable change in the $\mathrm { F e / N i }$ ratio.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: With increased exposure or irradiation time, the Zircaloy-2 matrix, therefore, gradually becomes more concentrated with dissolved alloying elements, increasingly approaching the overall alloy composition.

source_id: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_014_chunk36
evidence_span: The general increase in HPU percentage with channel exposure or time can be interpreted as a continuous change, or degradation, in the protectiveness of the interfacial oxide layer as the matrix and hence oxide composition evolve.
